PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Thomas McCrea
Address: 1406 1st Ave N.E., Moose Jaw
Birthplace: Brandon, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? .....1901..........
Where did you set up housekeeping? .....Old Wives district..........
Where had you been living before that? .....East of Ks.....Ontario..........
For how many people did you prepare meals? .....Generally 2 or 3..........
How far was it to your nearest store? .....2 1/2 miles..........
How often could a visit be made to the store? .....Biweekly monthly..........
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? .....Sugar tea coffee, dried fruit, toilet soap & others..........

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? .....Frisco Royal Household..........
In what quantities did you buy it? .....Quite often.....100 lbs..........
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? .....2.50 to 2.75 for 100..........
How much did you use graham flour? .....Basically none..........
Whole wheat flour? .....very little..........
Was flour milled locally? .....No.... How far away? .....x.... What year? .....x..........
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? .....50..........
What other grain products did you use? ...................................
Cornmeal? .....yes........ Whole Wheat? .....very little Farina? .....none..........
Other? .....x..........
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? .....No..... some for flour..........
How did you grind it? .....Hand grinder..........

How did you get fresh meat? Only in winter months

How did you preserve meat? Canned beef + dried beef + cured + smoked pork

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No

If so what year was it organized? X

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Ducks, geese, prairie chickens & an odd antelope

For how long? Throughout winter

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not extensively

Canned salmon

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Frozen fish in winter

Kinds? White fish, pike, perch, etc.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

In earliest years, many products were sold in bulk. Today, almost all food products are packaged in attractive packages.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Porridge with milk & cream, with toast with some, fruits, jam &c. Dinner & suppers; much the same as today. More cured meat was consumed then than present.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1931. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Roast chicken with all the trimmings

Mr & Mrs J.A. Lenton about 50 yrs old

I knew of no one without plenty to eat, although sometimes the variety was limited.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Porridge with milk & cream, sweet bread with jam, fruit, jam & tea. Dinner & suppers, much the same as today. More canned meat since concerned then at present.

Sometimes the variety was limited
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

I see no particular difference.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

More groceries of a varied nature were purchased when the railroad came near, about 1910. At that time people in the farming district depended much on local products.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

The main difference in earliest years was that more goods were bought in larger amounts. Of course there was not the variety to choose from & prices were only a fraction of today's prices. In storage each family had their own system & not many perishable goods were purchased.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

More groceries of a varied nature, were purchased when the railroad came over, about 1918.

With the people in the farming district depend much on local products.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days. In your own words, include not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of pages if more space is needed).

The main difference in earliest years, were more goods were bought in larger amounts.

Of course there was not the variety to choose from as prices were only a fraction of today's prices.

As to storage, each family had their own system.

Not many perishable goods were purchased.
